chapter.title: Documentation
chapter.para: The CodeX documentation, including the user guide, the installation guide, and of course this programmer guide, is generated from the DocBook format. The aim of this chapter is to explain the generation process of the CodeX documentation, in order to improve it and/or make it upgrade.

section.title: Documentation with DocBook
section.para: This section is not a DocBook Tutorial. It focuses on the CodeX documentation generation process.

DocBook provides a system for writing structured documents using SGML or XML. One of the big advantage of DocBook is that you can generate your documentation in various format with only one source files. For instance, the CodeX User Guide is currently generated in 3 formats :
PDF
multi-page HTML
single-page HTML

The generation is controlled by different XSL stylesheets, as shown in and .

section.title: Documentation directory structure
section.para:
All the documentation files, including XML files, screenshots, images, slides and scripts are located in the directory testserver/httpd/documentation/.
Except the main documentation generation script, located in testserver/utils/
All the paths given in this section are given as relative to this directory. In this directory, we can find one directory by available guide (installation guide, administration guide, developer guide, user guide). We will focus on the user guide, which is the more complete and complex structure. We can find almost the same structure for the other directories.
cmd : generation scripts.
xml2html.sh : script for HTML generation
xml2fo.sh and fo2pdf.sh : script for PDF generation
In these scripts, you can find the java call to saxon, with the main XSL stylesheet.
html : the html generated files, subdivided into language directory (en_US/, fr_FR/, etc...).
icons : images and icons required in the documentation, like the CodeX icons, etc...
pdf : the pdf generated files, subdivided into language directory (en_US/, fr_FR/, etc...).
screenshots : screenshots used in the documentation. OpenOffice files used to generate the screenshots (with comments) are also stored in this directory. As the screenshots are localized, the directory is subdivided into language directory (en_US/, fr_FR/, etc...)
slides : slides (and corresponding images files) used in the documentation. The directory is subdivided into language directory (en_US/, fr_FR/, etc...)
xml : documentation source files (in DocBook format). The directory is subdivided into language directory (en_US/, fr_FR/, etc...)
In a language directory, the main file, called CodeX_User_Guide.xml, include all the chapters to make the final book.
In the xml root directory, the non-localized files ParametersDefault.dtd and ParametersDefault.dtd provide respectively site specific information and local customization.
xsl : XSL files to generate the documentation into many formats.
common : contains common files for any generated format.
l10n.xml : available languages declaration. Update this file to add a language.
<language>.xml : Generated text (like chapter, section, bibliography keywords) translation. If you want to add a new entry, don't forget to add it in every <language>.xml available file.
fo : contains XSL stylesheet to convert XML into FO.
docbook_<language>.xsl : main XSL stylesheet. Do the imports of all the others XSL files. Define the language for the generated text. Must be one of similar file per available language. This file is called by the cmd/xml2fo.sh script.
html : contains all XSL files to convert XML into HTML.
param.xsl defines some parameters, like the place for figures, the revision history inclusion or not, etc ...
This file is called by the xsl/htmlhelp/htmlhelp_<language>.xsl file to generate the multi-page HTML documentation.
param_onechunk.xsl defines some parameters, like the place for figures, the revision history inclusion or not, etc ...
This file is called by the xsl/htmlhelp/htmlhelp_onechunk_<language>.xsl file to generate the simple-page HTML documentation.
htmlhelp : main XSL files called by cmd/xml2html.sh script to generate HTML documentation.
htmlhelp_<language>.xsl stands for including all XSL files needed to generate the multi-page HTML documentation
htmlhelp_onechunk_<language>.xsl stands for including all XSL files needed to generate the simple-page HTML documentation

section.title: How to add a language?
section.para: Currently, the documentation (user guide) can be generated in two languages (english and french). In order to add a language, here are the things to do:

listitem.para: Create a new file documentation/user_guide/xsl/common/<new_language>.xml copying an existing documentation/user_guide/xsl/common/<existing_language>.xml file. This file is to localize the generated text (like Table of content, Figure, etc...). Keep the key and translate all values. A lot of languages are already available in the original DocBook distribution. Just be aware of some added key for the CodeX needs (like Authors, author, Description, etc...).

Create a new file documentation/user_guide/xsl/htmlhelp/htmlhelp_<new_language>.xsl copying an existing htmlhelp_<existing_language>.xsl file. This file is the xsl file to generate the chunked HTML documentation (multi HTML files). Change the line <xsl:param name="l10n.gentext.language" select="'en'"/> with the new language (the language code is the short one, the same as given to the XML file just above).

Create a new file documentation/user_guide/xsl/htmlhelp/htmlhelp_onechunk_<new_language>.xsl copying an existing htmlhelp_onechunk_<existing_language>.xsl file. This file is the xsl file to generate the onechunked HTML documentation (single HTML file). Change the line <xsl:param name="l10n.gentext.language" select="'en'"/> with the new language (the language code is the short one, the same as given to the XML file just above).

Create a new file documentation/user_guide/xsl/fo/docbook_<new_language>.xsl copying an existing fo/docbook_<existing_language>.xsl file. Change the line <xsl:param name="l10n.gentext.language" select="'en'"/> with the new language (the language code is the short one, the same as given to the XML file just above).
Edit the generate_doc.sh file and add the new language to the constant definition ALL_LANGUAGES; separated by a single space (ALL_LANGUAGES="en_US fr_FR de_DE").
